isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC), Orifice Tube System, Pre-March 2007 - 3200, 4100, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 7600, 7700, 8500, 8600 - REMOVE AND INSTALL - HEATER HOUSING

note.para: Removing and installing the heater housing requires detaching and raising the Instrument Panel (IP). Replacement of the heater housing is necessary only if either the mode door mechanism or the housing itself are damaged. In either case the entire heater housing is replaced as an assembly.

step1.para: Inside the cab, remove the A-pillar trim from the driver's side.
Remove the assist handle and the A-pillar trim from the passenger's side.

note.para: Refer to Figure 34 while performing the following procedures.

step1.para: Remove the five bolts (1) securing the top of the IP to the dash panel (located near the windshield).
Remove the two bolts (2) securing the steering column module to the IP.
Remove the two bolts (3) securing each side of the IP to the dash panel.

note.para: Refer to Figure 35 while performing the following procedures.

step1.para: To gain access to the mounting studs (6) for the heater housing (1), the evaporator housing (7) must be removed from the cowl. Refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, AIR CONDITIONER (EVAPORATOR) HOUSING
Remove the heater core (4) and related components, refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, HEATER CORE, .
Disconnect the HVAC wiring harness (3) from the instrument panel wiring harness.

note.para: It may be possible to remove the heater housing without disconnecting the passenger side floor duct (10); however, the following steps are provided as an alternative.
The driver side duct (5) is connected to the heater housing with a snap mount (slip-lock). This duct is also mounted to the dash panel with one mounting screw.

There are two gaskets attached to the exterior of the heater housing. There is one gasket (8) where the housing mounts to the dash panel; and another gasket (9) where the IP rests on top of the housing. Try not to damage the gaskets when moving the housing or the IP.
In the following step, it will be necessary to raise the IP slightly while removing the heater housing. This may require a second or third person.

step1.para: Lift the IP and brace it so that it provides the greatest amount of clearance for removing the heater housing.

Disconnect passenger side floor duct (10) from the heater housing. It is mounted to the side of the housing with one screw. The top of the duct is connected to the housing with a snap mount (slip-lock), and is disconnected by pulling the duct away from the housing.
Remove the mounting screw (11) for the driver side floor duct (5) and move the duct to the left to disconnect it from the housing.
On the engine side of the dash panel, remove the four nuts (6) from the heater housing mounting studs.
Pull the heater housing to the rear (to allow its mounting studs to clear the dash panel). The heater housing (1) should now be clear to slide out from under the IP.

If the mode door actuator motor (2) is being transferred to a replacement housing, remove the two screws securing the actuator motor to the heater housing (1), and pull the actuator straight off of the mode door shaft.

note.para: A new heater housing is supplied with the passenger side floor duct installed. It may be possible to install the heater housing without removing the passenger side floor duct; however, the following procedure is provided as an alternative installation method.
Refer to Figure 35 while performing the following procedures.

step1.para: Disconnect passenger side floor duct (10) from the new heater housing. It is mounted to the side of the housing with one screw. The top of the duct is connected to the housing with a snap mount (slip-lock), and is disconnected by pulling the duct away from the housing.

Carefully slip the mode door actuator motor (2) from the removed housing, onto the end of the mode door shaft so that the mounting holes are properly aligned, if possible. Secure the actuator with two screws. If alignment is necessary:

step2.para: Place the actuator into its approximate position.
Connect a 9 Volt battery across pins A and B of the actuator connector, to rotate the drive collar. (Reverse the connection to rotate the drive collar in the opposite direction.)
Allow the drive collar to rotate until it is aligned with the door shaft, and the actuator mounting screws can be inserted. Then, disconnect 9 Volt battery.

note.para: In the following step, the IP must be raised slightly while installing the heater housing. This may require a second or third person. To insure proper alignment and compression of the heater housing top gasket, the IP must remain raised until the heater housing is securely mounted.
While performing the following steps be careful not to damage the gaskets when moving the heater housing or the IP.

step1.para: Lift the IP and brace it so that it provides the greatest amount of clearance for installing the heater housing.
Position the passenger side floor duct (10) under the IP, approximately in its final position.
With the IP raised, carefully position the heater housing (1) under the passenger side instrument panel, so that its mounting studs protrude through the matching holes in the dash panel.
Connect the top of the passenger side floor duct (10) to the outlet of the heater housing (1). This is a slip-lock type snap joint.
On the engine side of the dash panel, secure the heater housing by installing four nuts (6) on the mounting studs. Tighten to 6500 N.mm (57.5 lbf-in).
Secure the passenger side floor duct to the side of the heater housing using one screw.

note.para: The driver side duct (5) is connected to the heater housing with a snap mount (slip-lock).

step1.para: Connect the driver's side floor duct (5) to the heater housing by slipping the end of the duct over the heater housing outlet. Secure the floor duct to the dash panel under the instrument panel using its mounting screw (11).
Carefully allow the IP to return to its normal resting position.
Connect the HVAC wiring harness (3) to the instrument panel wiring harness.
Install heater core (4) and related components, refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, HEATER CORE, .
Install evaporator housing (7) onto the cowl. Refer to REMOVE AND INSTALL, AIR CONDITIONER (EVAPORATOR) HOUSING

note.para: Refer to Figure 34 while performing the following procedures.

step1.para: Install the two bolts (3) securing each side of the IP to the dash panel.
Install the two bolts (2) securing the steering column module to the IP.
Install the five bolts (1) securing the top of the IP to the dash panel (located near the windshield).
Inside the cab, install the assist handle and the A-pillar trim on the passenger's side.
Install the A-pillar trim on the driver's side.
